revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox airport | name = Bezymyanka | nativename = Безымянка | nativename-a = | nativename-r = | image = | image-width = | caption = | IATA = local ({{lang-ru|СБЫ}}) | ICAO = UWWG | type = experimental | owner = | operator = [http://www.aviacor.ru/ JSC Aviakor] | city-served = | location = [[Samara, Russia|Samara]] | elevation-f = | elevation-m = 41 | coordinates = {{coord|53|13|N|50|20|E|type:airport|display=inline,title}} | website = | metric-elev = | metric-rwy = | r1-number = 02/20 | r1-length-f = | r1-length-m = 2800х45 | r1-surface = [[Concrete]] | stat-year = | stat1-header = | stat1-data = | stat2-header = | stat2-data = | footnotes = }} '''Bezymyanka Airport''' is an experimental [[aerodrome]] in the [[Aviakor]] aviation plant in the city of [[Samara, Russia|Samara]]. It is located {{convert|4|km|mi}} east of the Bezymyanka railroad station in the [[Kirov, Russia|Kirov district]] of Samara, {{convert|12|km|mi}} east of the city center.
To the east of the airport, the [[Smyshlyaevka]] airport is located. To the south, the settlements [[Chkalov]], Padovka, and the [[Samara River]]. To the north, the Aviakor aviation plant and the [[TsSKB-Progress]] plant.
The airport has a class 1 rating and can serve most airplane and helicopter types. The total runway length is {{convert|3600|m|feet}}.
Founded in 1942, the first runway utilized bricks as its pavement. After [[World War II]] , the aviation plants 1 and 18 were evacuated to Kuibyshev (now known as Samara) from [[Moscow]] and [[Voronezh]]. At the earliest possible date they set up the production of [[Il-2]] aircraft.
In the second part of the 20th century, the airport served as the testing ground for a number of [[Tupolev]], [[Ilyushin]] and [[Antonov]] aircraft produced by the above mentioned aviation plants.
Since 1958, plant 1 was redesigned for the production of [[space rocket]]s and [[artificial satellite]]s. The airport also started a charter transportation service to [[Baikonur Cosmodrome|Baikonur]] and [[Plesetsk Cosmodrome|Plesetsk]], which continue today. In 1980, the airport was used to transport components of the [[Energia]] rocket carrier to [[Baikonur (spaceport)|Baikonur]] on the [[VM-T]] aircraft in preparation for the [[Buran Shuttle]] flight. The runway was extended to a length of {{convert|3600|m|feet}}.
==References== * {{Ru icon}} [http://a9.nm.ru/UWWG.gif UWWG.gif - scheme of the airport] * {{Ru icon}} [http://news.samaratoday.ru/news/112027/ History of Bezymyanka-65], Samara Today, April 9, 2007
